The invisible sides of war: because we refuse to learn.From Hanoi to Gaza.When America entered the war in Vietnam, it stepped into a conflict it didn‚Äôt understand. No grasp of the people. No grasp of the land.No idea how deeply rooted resistance can be when a nation is defending its home. Today, we see echoes of that same miscalculation. Putin believed Ukraine would fall in days. Netanyahu flirts with the idea that regime change in Tehran‚Äîby killing a few key leaders‚Äîcould be swift and surgically successful. But war doesn‚Äôt unfold in straight lines. In Vietnam, the more bombs America dropped‚ÄîB-52s, Napalm bombs , carpet bombing‚Äîthe more resilient the Vietnamese became.It happened again in Iraq. Again in Afghanistan. The ‚Äúmother of all bombs‚Äù was dropped. And still, more Afghans rose and won.From that wreckage came the Taliban. Came ISIS. Ghosts of wars that were meant to be won. Because here‚Äôs the hard truth: A foolish leader starts a war first‚Äîand calculates the cost later. War fueled by its own ashes.Victory on the battlefield it doesnt mean winning the war. The talks in Istanbul are unlikely to yield immediate results. Russia views them as an initial exchange rather than a decisive summit, with further meetings already expected on May 16.The core obstacle remains security guarantees. Russia insists on neutral peacekeeping forces, rejecting any NATO or U.S. presence, while Ukraine‚Äôs backers oppose troops from Russian-aligned blocs like the CSTO.Even as diplomats convened, the military operations continued. At night, Russian forces launched a wave of strikes across Ukraine, targeting military infrastructure from Sumy to Ivano-Frankivsk. The attacks, involving drones and missiles, highlight Russia‚Äôs ability to escalate at will, reinforcing its leverage at the negotiating table.Today‚Äôs negotiations are less about compromise than about positioning. Russia holds the initiative, both militarily and diplomatically, while Ukraine scrambles to reconcile Western demands with its weakening battlefield stance. Whether these talks lead to a pause in fighting or merely set the stage for further escalation will depend on whether Kyiv‚Äôs allies are willing to concede‚Äîor if Russia decides it can achieve more through force.

Although battles and wars are sometimes won by high stakes gambles, the strategic wisdom of the Kursk offensive was always questionable. It may be that in Kyiv‚Äôs high command, political rather than military considerations dominated the decision making. When the operation began, the U.S. election was looming very close and there was the need to strengthen support in both the Republican and Democratic camps as well as in Europe. Since the failed counter offensive in 2023, Western hopes that Ukraine might prevail had sharply fallen away, and after that, much political bandwidth was diverted to the Middle East. At Kursk, Kyiv hoped to galvanize international support through replicating the optimism created by successful counter attacks around Kharkiv and Kherson in 2022. With this PR stunt offensive Zelensky wanted to show the world that Ukraine was still in the fight and could win, if only provided the tools to do so. But by then it was too late. Governments in the U.S. and Europe had given up on Ukraine being able to push the Russians out and were focused only on some kind of negotiated settlement. The Kursk offensive might prove to have been Ukraine‚Äôs most costly blunders during the SMO.

As of the morning on March 13, less than 110 square kilometers of the territory of the Kursk region remained under Ukrainian control. About 90% of the area has already been liberated. The losses of the Armed Forces of Ukraine amounted to over 68,000 people and more than 7,000 pieces of equipment. About 430 Ukrainain soldiers were captured as prisoners. Meanwhile, the battle for the main Ukrainian stronghold near Sudzha is gaining momentum. Almost all settlements on the outskirts of the agglomeration have been liberated, and the flanks of Ukrainian defense have been destroyed. On March 11, Russian troops had broken into the streets of Sudzha. By the morning of May 12, Russian flags were raised in the center of the town. The town in its administrative border was liberated, the mop up operations is ongoing. Ukrainian forces have retreated across the river and are trying to hold defense in Goncharovka located on the western outskirts of the agglomeration. Ukrainian resistance in the village is aimed at securing the roads to escape from the region, but the intense Russian fire inflicts heavy losses on the scattered Ukrainian forces. Most Ukrainian soldiers abandon their vehicles and other precious military equipment from NATO, trying to flee from the Russian territory by foot through the forests. Kiev is trying its best to hide the defeat. The Ukrainian military command called the flight from the Kursk region ‚Äúan organized regrouping to more advantageous positions.‚Äù Zelensky keeps lying, claiming that the Ukrainian army performs the tasks of maintaining positions in an organized manner. The Commander-in-Chief Syrsky fired General Krasilnikov, who was in charge of the operation in the Kursk region. Kiev no longer recalls its plan to exchange the captured Russian territory to some areas in the Donbass. Many people here say that one side is solely responsible for the conflict. But let‚Äôs consider a hypothetical situation: imagine that in countries neighboring the United States, Americans start facing severe discrimination, their culture is suppressed, and they are placed in increasingly unsafe conditions, forcing them to flee their homes and relocate to small towns. These towns are then subjected to daily shelling, while hostile military forces surround them. At the same time, these neighboring countries begin to strengthen ties with America‚Äôs geopolitical rivals, hosting their military bases and weapons. With Russia, North Korea and China in particular. How long would the U.S. tolerate such a situation?This thought experiment highlights that complex conflicts rarely have a simple, one-sided truth. Any country in such a position would respond in some way. It‚Äôs crucial to understand the causes and consequences rather than reducing everything to a black-and-white perspective.

The invisible sides of war: because we refuse to learn. From Hanoi to Gaza. When America entered the war in Vietnam, it stepped into a conflict it didn‚Äôt understand. No grasp of the people. No grasp of the land. No idea how deeply rooted resistance can be when a nation is defending its home. Today, we see echoes of that same miscalculation. Putin believed Ukraine would fall in days. Netanyahu flirts with the idea that regime change in Tehran‚Äîby killing a few key leaders‚Äîcould be swift and surgically successful. But war doesn‚Äôt unfold in straight lines. In Vietnam, the more bombs America dropped‚ÄîB-52s, Napalm bombs , carpet bombing‚Äîthe more resilient the Vietnamese became. It happened again in Iraq. Again in Afghanistan. The ‚Äúmother of all bombs‚Äù was dropped. And still, more Afghans rose and won. From that wreckage came the Taliban. Came ISIS. Ghosts of wars that were meant to be won. Because here‚Äôs the hard truth: A foolish leader starts a war first‚Äîand calculates the cost later. War fueled by its own ashes. Victory on the battlefield it doesn t mean winning the war. And without that‚Ä¶ the war is never truly over‚Ä¶..

The number of damaged aircraft is around 10 to 13, some of them badly damaged beyond repair, but these are very very old Soviet bombers, even Tu22 (not to be confused with Tu22M which is a newer and much better model), which have not been used since 1980 (probably used for training). The aircraft in Belaya or Srednii as it is known today are quite old and of limited value, they also did not participate in Ukraine. To top it all off, a group of truck drivers prevented most of the attacks, they climbed onto trucks and smashed many drones with rocks. They will be awarded medals for bravery for this action. let us list the facts and you can decide who you think is winning in the Russo-Ukraine war. Russia invaded and occupied 38% of Ukraine in early 2022, but by October 22 after retreating in the east and up to today in 2025 they only managed to hang on to just 17%. That s a decrease in the Russian temporarily occupied territories of 61%% ! (in real terms Russia in 3 years has only captured 10% new territory in Ukraine. here s why that s a fact - In 2014 Russia annexed Crimea - 4.7% of Ukraine. between 2015 &amp 2021 Russia occupied part of Donetsk (Donbas) - 2.3% of Ukraine, that equals 7% already occupied, prior to the 2022 invasion, meaning Russia has only captured 10% new territory in 3yrs 3months of war ! üò≥ üò≤) Russia got defeated at Kyiv and had to retreat back to Belarus ! Russia got defeated in Sumi and Kharkiv and ran away into Kursk and Belgorod leaving millions of tons of equipment for Ukraine ! Russia got defeated in Kherson and had to retreat back across the Dnieper River ! Ukraine invades Kursk in Russia and captures in 9 days, more territory than Russia captured in Donbas over 2 years ! who do you think is winning the land war? Ukraine made Sevastapol in Crimea untenable for the Black Sea Fleet, making them leave their major regional naval base ! Ukraine has in dock and on the open sea sunk or neutralised 450,000 tons of Russia s black sea fleet, approx 67% of the fleet is unusable! Ukrainian activities in the Black Sea has forced the Russian black sea fleet to retreat all the way (600km east) to Novorossiysk in Russia. The Russian black sea fleet has barricaded itself inside Novorossiysk harbour to stop drones attacks from Ukraine, scared to come out. Ukraine has made the Black and Azov Seas untenable for Russia s mighty black sea fleet and taken control the Black Sea region. who do you think is winning the sea war ? Russia s air space force in January 2022 was 7 times bigger than Ukraine s. Russia has lost 408 planes, 392 helicopters and 616 pilots in 3 years 3 months of war. Russian airforce won t fly in Ukraine air space for fear of being shot down by Ukraine s air defence systems. in 3 years 3 months of war, out numbering Ukraine s air force 7 : 1, Russia HAS NOT managed to take control of Ukraine s airspace. Russia can t make enough planes to replace those being shot down or destroyed, but Ukraine has received new planes from their supporters. so who do you think is winning the air war? on top of this Russian casualties currently exceed 990,000+ soldiers and military equipment losses over 160,000+ pieces. You might want to re-evaluate your understanding of what has been going on and who s winning this fight!
